name: transmission network construction, electricity, high voltage | transmission network, electricity, high voltage | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/7800/documentation

This dataset describes the infrastructure (masts, cables etc.) of the electricity high voltage transmission network in Switzerland. It represents an average of underground cable and aerial lines per km of high voltage electricity transmission grid infrastructure. Switching stations are not included in this dataset, since switching stations for voltage transformation from high to medium voltage level are attributed to the medium voltage level and transformers from medium to low voltage level are attributed to the low voltage level.;The high voltage level is considred above 24 kV. Sometimes a highest voltage level is distinguished from the high voltage level grid; both are merged in this dataset. Typically large scale industry is supplied from this voltage level (Itten et al. 2014). Most power generation feeds into the high voltage grid.;Reference(s): René Itten, Rolf Frischknecht, Matthias Stucki, 2014, Life Cycle Inventories of Electricity Mixes and Grid

The activity includes the land and material requirements of an average km of high voltage transmission grid infrastructrure in Switzerland.

The activity ends with the disposal of the waste materials. It is assumed that 80 % of the cables are recycled.
category: F:Construction/42:Civil engineering/422:Construction of utility projects/4220:Construction of utility projects

processDocumentation.timeDescription: This dataset is based on a study by Itten et. al (2014), which is based on a number of literature sources representing the years 2010 and 2011. Due to the long lifetime, as well as project planning and construction times of ectricity transmission and distribution infrastructure, the 2010 situation is considered valid at least until 2020.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Average of high voltage underground cable (1843km) and aerial line (13988km) in Switzerland in 2010 (Itten et al. 2014).;The lifetime of the network is assumed to be 30 years (lifetime of most individual components assumed 40 years).
